tabs.caption: An introduction to the foundational principles of Anekāntavād, the Jain theory of non-absolutism.

items.content: Anekāntavād, literally meaning 'the multiplicity and relativity of viewpoints,' is a central tenet of Jain philosophy. It posits that reality is complex and multifaceted, and truth can be viewed from various perspectives. From the Jain standpoint, it is possible to overcome the apparent inconsistencies between different views to grasp the underlying truth. It argues that any single viewpoint represents only a partial truth and that absolute truth is the sum of all these partial, relative viewpoints. This principle fosters tolerance and a comprehensive understanding of reality.

items.header: The Parable of the Blind Men and an Elephant
items.content: This classic story elegantly demonstrates Anekāntavād. Six blind men each touch a different part of an elephant—the leg, tail, trunk, ear, belly, and tusk—and each concludes the elephant is like a pillar, a rope, a python, a fan, a drum, and a pipe, respectively. They argue, each certain of their own conclusion. A wise person explains they are all partially correct, as they only perceived a fraction of the whole reality. This teaches us that non-omniscient beings have limited knowledge. Only an omniscient being (Kevali) can perceive the whole truth. Thus, we should express our views with humility, acknowledging they are true only from our limited perspective.

The tradition of Jain logic is rich and ancient. Key figures who shaped its development between the 5th and 16th centuries include:
  • Shri Siddhasen Diwākar: Author of the Nyāyāvatāra, the earliest systematic manual on Jain logic.
  • Mallavādi
  • Haribhadra-suri
  • Akalank
  • Virsen
  • Vidyānandi
  • Devasuri
  • Āchārya Hemchandra
  • Yashovijayaji: A highly influential 16th-century logician who synthesized and advanced the work of his predecessors.

Anekāntavād is not just a philosophical doctrine but a guide for ethical living. Its application encourages one to:
  • Develop a strong urge to seek truth.
  • Believe in many possibilities and not insist on a single approach.
  • Accept partial truths expressed by others, even adversaries.
  • Exercise equanimity towards all.
When combined with Ahimsā (non-violence) and Aparigraha (non-possessiveness), it promotes universal friendship, social equity, reconciliation of differences, and ecological conservation.

tabs.caption: Explore the Tripadi—the three-fold principle of origination, destruction, and permanence that defines every substance.

tabData.title: Tripadi: The Three-fold Nature of Substance

items.content:
Shraman Bhagawān Mahāvir established the foundation of Jain philosophy in three phrases, known as the Tripadi:
1. Uppannei Vä (Utpād): Origination. This denotes the emergence of a new mode or phase of a substance.
2. Vigamei Vä (Vyaya): Destruction. This denotes the disappearance or vanishing of an old mode.
3. Dhuvei Vä (Dhrauvya): Permanence. This denotes that the original, essential qualities of the substance remain constant throughout the changes.

The Jain term for a substance or existence is Sat. Every Sat has three aspects:
Dravya (Substance): The permanent, underlying substance itself which is not destroyable.
Guna (Qualities): The inseparable and permanent essence or attributes of a substance.
Paryāya (Modes): The constantly changing, transient forms or states of a substance. While modes (Paryāya) are always changing, the substance (Dravya) and its qualities (Guna) persist.

Example 1: Gold
  • Dravya: Gold.
  • Guna: Yellowness, malleability, etc.
  • Paryāya: Bar, chain, bangle.
When a gold bar (old Paryāya) is melted to make a chain (new Paryāya), the mode of 'bar' is destroyed (Vyaya) and the mode of 'chain' is originated (Utpād). Throughout this transformation, the gold itself (Dravya) and its inherent qualities (Guna) remain permanent (Dhrauvya).

Example 2: Soul
  • Dravya: Soul.
  • Guna: Knowledge (Jnān), bliss (Ānand), energy (Virya).
  • Paryāya: Childhood, youth, old age; a human body, a celestial body.
The soul persists through different life stages and different bodies, which are all transient modes (Paryāya). The soul (Dravya) and its core qualities (Guna) are permanent.

tabData.title: Jain Epistemology: How to Know a Substance
tabData.description: This mindmap illustrates the four categories used in Jain philosophy to understand a substance completely, from its basic characteristics to the analysis of its meaning in different contexts.

nodes.description: The unique characteristic present only in a specific substance and no other. E.g., consciousness (chetanā) is the Lakshan of a soul.
True and complete knowledge of a substance from all angles, without limitations or doubts.
Direct knowledge gained without the medium of senses or mind. Includes Avadhi Jnān, Manah-paryav Jnān, and Keval-jnān.
Indirect knowledge gained through the senses, mind, or scriptures. Includes Mati Jnān and Shrut-jnän.
A partial point of view that grasps only one aspect of an object. It is a valid but incomplete truth.
The analysis of truth through language; exploring how a single word can have different meanings based on context.
Referring to an object by its conventional name, regardless of its qualities. E.g., calling a poor man 'Indra'.
Referring to an object through its representation or symbol. E.g., an idol of Mahāvir Swāmi.
Referring to an object based on its past or future state. E.g., calling a prince a 'king'.
Referring to an object based on its present state and function. E.g., a person is a king only while actively ruling.

tabData.title: Fundamental Concepts in Anekāntavād
tabData.description: Learn the essential Sanskrit terms and their meanings related to the Jain theory of multiplicity.

cards.back: The theory of multiplicity or non-absolutism; the doctrine that truth is multifaceted.
The inherent, inseparable qualities or attributes of a substance.
The transient modes, forms, or modifications of a substance.
Origination or emergence of a new mode (Paryāya).
Destruction or disappearance of an old mode (Paryāya).
Permanence; the constant nature of the substance (Dravya) through all changes.
Existence or being; a substance that has the three aspects: Dravya, Guna, and Paryāya.
A partial point of view; knowledge of a substance from a specific perspective.
Complete, true, and valid knowledge of a substance in its entirety.
A method of analysis of truth; the four ways a word can convey meaning (Name, Symbol, Potentiality, Actuality).
The earliest known Jain manual on logic, composed by Shri Siddhasen Diwākar.
The substantial point of view, which focuses on the permanence of the substance.
The modal point of view, which focuses on the changing modes of the substance.
The unique characteristic that defines a substance.

tabs.caption: A brief timeline highlighting some of the most influential figures in the history of Jain logic.

tabData.era: The Golden Age of Jain Logic

events.title: The Pioneer: Siddhasen Diwākar (c. 5th Century CE)
events.description: A Shvetāmbar Āchārya who is credited with composing the Nyāyāvatāra, the earliest systematic Jain manual on logic. He established a formal foundation for Jain epistemology, setting the stage for future philosophical discourse.

events.title: Era of Great Logicians (c. 6th - 13th Century CE)
events.description: Following Siddhasen Diwākar, a series of brilliant Jain thinkers like Mallavādi, Haribhadra-suri, Akalank, Virsen, Vidyānandi, Devasuri, and Āchārya Hemchandra expanded upon and debated logical principles. They actively participated in philosophical dialogues with other Indian schools of thought, defending and refining Jain doctrines.

events.title: The Great Synthesizer: Yashovijayaji (c. 16th Century CE)
events.description: A prominent and prolific Jain philosopher and logician who is often seen as the culmination of this great logical tradition. He synthesized the works of his predecessors and made significant contributions to Jain philosophy, logic, and ethics, leaving a lasting impact.
